ABSTRACT Polyhydroxyalkanoate (PHA), a well-known biodegradable polymer, features β-lactones as its monomers, which can be selectively synthesized through ring-expansion carbonylation of epoxides using well-defined [Lewis acid]+[Co(CO)4]– catalysts. However, the decomposition of [Co(CO)4]– species at temperatures exceeding 80 °C presents a hurdle for the development of commercially viable processes under high-temperature reaction conditions to reduce reaction time. Drawing insights from stable {(acyl)Co(CO) n } intermediates involved in historical HCo(CO)4-catalyzed hydroformylation processes, we sought to the high-temperature catalytic activity of epoxide ring-expansion carbonylation. The developed catalyst system, [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] and [(TPP)CrCl], exhibited exceptional catalytic performance with an unprecedented initial turnover frequency of 4700 h–1 at 100 °C and a turnover numbers of 93000. Notably, the catalyst displayed outstanding stability, operating at 80 °C for 168 h while selectively generating β-lactones. Graphical Abstract In epoxide carbonylation to β-lactones, we addressed the limited TON issue associated with the reported catalyst [LA]+[Co(CO)4]–. The designed catalyst system, consisting of [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] and [(TPP)CrCl], demonstrated remarkable catalytic performance, achieving an unprecedented initial TOF of 4700 h–1 at 100 °C and TON of 93000. Keywords Epoxide carbonylation β-Lactone Cobalt tetracarbonyl Acyl cobalt carbonyl High-temperature catalytic activity 1 Introduction In recent years, the epoxide ring-expansion carbonylation reaction has attracted considerable attention for its unique ability to selectively produce β-lactones [1–55], vital components of PHAs renowned for their marine biodegradability [56–59]. Notably, these β-lactones find versatile applications in the production of various compounds, including acrylic acid, succinic acid, butanediol, and THF derivatives, emphasizing their significance across a spectrum of chemical synthesis pathways (Scheme 1 ) [60–62]. The origins of this research track back to 1963, particularly driven by the work of Heck [63], with the use of HCo(CO)4 in a stoichiometric reaction. Subsequent advancements in the late 20th century led to the development of ring-expansion carbonylation catalysis using Co2(CO)8 [23,24,27,28,31]. In the early 2000s, the Coates group introduced a bimetallic catalyst, [LA]+[Co(CO)4]–, where LA is Lewis acid, marking the initial exploration of the industrial potential of this reaction [1]. However, employing such catalytic reactions for β-lactone production presents various challenges, including addressing the cost-effectiveness of the catalyst, increasing TON, enhancing TOF for improved production efficiency, and developing processes for the separation of products and catalysts. To address these challenges, diverse research paths are being explored, including the investigation of Co nanocatalysts and [heterogeneous LA]+[Co(CO)4]– catalysts [34,36,39,44–55]. These catalysts, although having different forms, all utilize the [Co(CO)4]– species during the reaction process. Nanocatalysts generate the [Co(CO)4]– anion in situ and [heterogeneous LA]+[Co(CO)4]– catalysts incorporate [Co(CO)4]– to achieve charge balance and activity. Thus, it can be asserted that all reported catalysts for ring-expansion carbonylation to date rely on the [Co(CO)4]– species. While these catalysts selectively generate β-lactones from epoxides, their limitations are evident compared to the Coates catalyst, which utilizes the [Co(CO)4]– anion and exhibits superior TOF [53]. Consequently, there are constraints in enhancing TOF, a crucial factor for economically viable commercial production. To overcome this problem, recent research has explored alternative anions such as [Mn(CO)5]– [16], [Mo(CO)5Cl]–, and [Cp*Mo(CO)3]– (Cp*: pentamethylcyclopentadienyl) [42], in lieu of [Co(CO)4]–. However, successful β-lactone production with catalysts other than the [Co(CO)4]– anion remains elusive. Herein, efforts to enhance the TOF of epoxide ring expansion carbonylation are reported, starting with the high-temperature reactivity investigation of the well-defined [LA]+[Co(CO)4]– catalysts and extending to the utilization of novel Co-containing organometallic species. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and method Hexene oxide (HO) was purchased from TCI, and purified using drying with CaH2 (4 wt%) at 35 °C for overnight followed by distillation under vacuum (50 °C). The distilled HO was further purified using the process of freeze-pump-thaw, and dried with 4 Å molecular sieves under –20 °C for overnight in the glove box. Tetrahydrofuran (THF), dimethoxyethane (DME), diethyl ether, pentane, iodomethane (CH3I), iodomethane-d3 (CD3I), 1,3-bis(diphenylphosphino)propane (dppp), Co2(CO)8, bis(triphenylphosphine)iminium chloride ((PNP)Cl), 3,5-di-tert-butylsalicylaldehyde, 1,2-diaminobenzene, CrCl2, and NaOH were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co and used directly unless mentioned otherwise. THF, DME, diethyl ether and pentane were distilled with sodium/benzophenone under Argon. NaCo(CO)4 and (salph)CrCl were synthesized according to our previous reported procedure [51]. Chromium(III) tetraphenylporphine chloride ([(TPP)CrCl]) was applied by STREM company. 1H NMR spectra were recorded using a Bruker instrument (600 MHz) 2.2 Synthesis of [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] and [(Deuterated-acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] In a glove box, NaCo(CO)4 (1.0 g), dppp (2.1 g, 1 equivalent to NaCo(CO)4) and diethyl ether (100 mL) were added to a schlenk flask (250 mL) equipped with dropping funnel. After transferring the equipment to outside glove box, the flask was stirred under ice-water for 10 minutes and then purged with CO gas for several minutes. CH3I or CD3I (0.9 g, 1.2 equivalent) solution in diethyl ether (10 mL) was added dropwise to the flask under CO environment and allowed to react for 1 h under ice-water and 4 h at room temperature, respectively. After the reaction, the flask was transferred inside glove box and the solution was filtered under vacuum. The filtrate was concentrated under vacuum to give the residual solution of approximately 20 mL, to which was slowly added the pentane (20 mL) under stirring. After cooling the mixture in the refrigerator under –20 °C for overnight, it was filtered and washed with pentane to give a light-yellow product of 2.1 g (yield 71%). 2.3 HO carbonylation HO/[(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp]/[(TPP)CrCl] = 10000/1/1) In a typical reaction, a stainless steel reactor (100 mL) was charged with [(TPP)CrCl] (2.0 mg), [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] (1.6 mg), HO (2.856 g), and DME (2.856 g) under inert atmosphere in a glove box. The reactor was then pressurized with 60 bar of CO and maintained at 80 °C for 24 h. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, resulting in a pressure decrease to approximately 52 bar, indicating an 8 bar reduction from the initial CO pressure prior to epoxide carbonylation. Subsequently, the reactor was further cooled using a dry-ice/acetone bath, and excess gas was slowly released. The reaction mixture was then transferred to a vial, and its weight was recorded at 5.9 g. The crude product was characterized by ¹H NMR spectroscopy using naphthalene as an internal standard, yielding 93% for β-lactone. 2.4 HO carbonylation (HO/[(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp]/[(TPP)CrCl] = 50000/1/1) In a typical reaction, a stainless steel reactor (100 mL) was charged with [(TPP)CrCl] solution (0.5 g, 1.0 mg/g), [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] solution (0.5 g, 0.82 mg/g), HO (3.57 g), and DME (2.57 g) in a glove box. The reactor was then pressurized with 60 bar of CO and maintained at 80 °C for 50 h. After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, resulting in a pressure decrease to approximately 49 bar, indicating an 11 bar reduction from the initial CO pressure prior to epoxide carbonylation. Subsequently, the reactor was further cooled using a dry-ice/acetone bath, and excess gas was slowly released. The reaction mixture was then transferred to a vial, and its weight was recorded at 7.9 g. The crude product was characterized by ¹H NMR spectroscopy using naphthalene as an internal standard, yielding 95% for β-lactone. 3 Results and discussion One of the most straightforward methods to increase the TOF of any catalytic system is by elevating the reaction temperature. To explore this, we initially observed the TOF variation with temperature for the well-defined [(TPP)Cr(THF)2]+[Co(CO)4]– catalyst (1) (TPP = tetraphenylporphyrinato). The process was operated at a CO pressure of 60 bar, using 1-hexene oxide (HO) as the epoxide substrate and maintaining a substrate-to-catalyst ratio of 50000/1. The use of liquid HO, which has a higher boiling point compared to ethylene oxide or propylene oxide, minimized losses during catalyst evaluation and ensured reproducible performance. The results obtained at 60 and 80 °C revealed high selectivity (> 96%) in β-lactone production, with TON reaching 4000 at 60 °C and 7500 at 80 °C (Fig. S1). As temperature elevating to 100 °C, the TON reached 14000, with the yield of 28%, within a relatively prolonged reaction period (40 h), and most starting material HO was not consumed. Therefore, for the complete conversion of HO with a high selectivity of β-lactone, developing a more efficient epoxide carbonylation catalyst is significant. In pursuit of more stable species altering for the [Co(CO)4]– species, attention was directed towards traditional cobalt-catalyzed hydroformylation processes employed in industry (Fig. S2) [64–67]: The first generation of hydroformylation catalyst was HCo(CO)4. However, due to the instability of [Co(CO)4]–, next-generation hydroformylation catalysts were introduced with the addition of phosphine ligands (HCo(CO)3(PR3)). In the second generation of hydroformylation, a crucial intermediate was observed; the coordinatively unsaturated acyl cobalt species (acyl)Co(CO)2L (L = CO or phosphine ligand) underwent hydrogenation via oxidative addition of H2 followed by reductive elimination of aldehyde. Notably, the acyl cobalt species are stable under high-temperature reaction conditions, leading this industrial reaction operating at high temperatures ranging from 100 to 180 °C. The acyl cobalt intermediate (acyl)Co(CO)2L with 16 valence electrons is strongly stabilized by the η 2 coordination or agostic interaction of the acyl group [64,65,68–71]. Based on the previous literature, a hypothesis emerged that a high-temperature stable cobalt complex with the {(acyl)Co(CO)2} motif might replace [Co(CO)4]– as the nucleophile in epoxide carbonylation, leading to potential improvements in both the stability and activity of the catalyst system during the carbonylation process. However, the contemplated {(acyl)Co(CO)2} motif possesses only 14 valence electrons at the central metal ion, rendering it inherently unstable and necessitating two more two-electron donor ligands. To achieve this goal, the chelate 1,3-bis(diphenylphosphino)propane (dppp)-modified cobalt acyl compound was chosen, as chelate phosphine ligands provide better stability than monophosphine ligands. The dppp-modified cobalt acyl compound was successfully synthesized following Heck's reported procedure, resulting in a light-yellow powder [72]. The structure of [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] was confirmed using 1H NMR and FTIR spectra (Figs. S3 and S4), which matched the reported data [73]. Additionally, [(TPP)CrCl] was selected as a LA due to its higher activity compared to other LA's in the ring-expansion carbonylation [52]. The catalytic performance of the [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp]/[(TPP)CrCl] catalyst system 2 was evaluated in the carbonylation of HO (Table 1). The epoxide carbonylation took place in a 100 mL stainless steel tube reactor using 2 (the ratio of species Co:Cr:HO = 1:1:10000) in dimethoxyethane (DME) at 80 °C under 60 bar CO for 24 h. The crude product was analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 1 , nearly all starting material HO was consumed, and the peaks at 4.5 ppm (L3) along with 3.5 (L2), 3.0 (L1), 1.7–1.8 (L4), 1.3–1.5 (L5,L6), and 0.9 (L7) ppm clearly indicate the corresponding β-lactone as the major product, along with trace amounts of ketone, aldehyde, 1-hexene, and 3-butyloxetan-2-one (an isomer of the target β-lactone). The formed products were further confirmed by gas chromatography (GC)-mass spectrometry, identifying major species with molecular weight of 128.2 g/mol (Fig. S5). The results are summarized in Table 1 . The catalyst system 2 showed a successful conversion of HO to the target β-lactone with an excellent yield, comparable to the performance of the reported catalyst [(TPP)Cr(THF)2]+[Co(CO)4]– (Table 1, entries 1 and 2, Fig. S6). Additionally, when the carbonylation using 2 was performed under 30 bar and 10 bar CO pressure at 80 °C, the achieved yields were 24% and no detectable β-lactone, respectively (Table 1, entries 3 and 4, Fig. S7). The carbonylation activity of 2 exhibited a moderate CO pressure dependence, leading to all subsequent carbonylations being conducted at an elevated pressure of 60 bar CO. Interestingly, when the reaction using 2 was conducted at 60 °C, a typical temperature for [(porphyrin derivative)Cr]+[Co(CO) 4 ]–-catalyzed epoxide carbonylation [4], no β-lactone was detected (Table 1, entry 5). This result indicates that the [(TPP)Cr(THF)2]+[Co(CO)4]– catalyst is more reactive than catalyst system 2 at 60 °C. Based on the above results, both 2 and [(TPP)Cr(THF)2]+[Co(CO)4]– being highly active at 80 °C and no detectable activity for 2 at 60 °C, we further evaluated the activity of 2 at 80 °C using a HO/cobalt ratio of 50000 elevated from 10000 (Fig. 2 ). All epoxide was converted within 50 h at 80 °C, leading to a β-lactone yield of 95% (Fig. S8) with the TON of 47500, which is significantly higher than 12000 for catalyst [(TPP)Cr(THF)2]+[Co(CO)4]– (1) under the same reaction conditions. Notably, only 10% yield of β-lactone observed in the initial 10 h and subsequently the reaction rate rapidly increased, suggesting the catalyst system 2 required activation, possibly by the generation of a coordinately unsaturated cobalt site via the dissociation of the phosphine ligand. These results underscore the substantial enhancement in activity achieved with catalyst system 2 in the epoxide carbonylation. With this result in hand, a much higher HO/cobalt species ratio of 100000 was used to run the reaction at 80 °C. During this time, a TON of 93000 for the target β-lactone was achieved (Table 1, entry 6, Fig. S9). The other substrate PO carbonylation was also studied using catalyst system 2 (Table S1), which is slightly lower activity compared to that of HO carbonylation. At a high TON PO carbonylation of 50000, the yield of β-butyrolactone reached 83% in 72 h, corresponding to TON of 41500. The activity of catalyst system 2 was further investigated at elevated temperatures of 90 and 100 °C (Fig. S10). It was found that the catalyst activation time was clearly reduced as the reaction temperature increased. At 90 °C, in the initial 10 h, the TON of β-lactone reached 25000, much higher than that of observed TON 5000 at 80 °C within the same initial time. At 100 °C, the TON of the target β-lactone reached 23500 in just the initial 5 h, with an impressive TOF of 4700 h–1. Notably, this TOF is the highest ever reported for epoxide carbonylation, surpassing the previously reported highest TOF of 1670 h–1 for the catalyst [(OEP)Cr(THF)2]+[Co(CO)4]– (OEP = octaethylporphyrinato) (neat epoxide, 60 °C, 6 h) [4]. Importantly, at both 90 and 100 °C, the TON continued to increase with reaction time, suggesting that the catalyst remained active at the end of the carbonylation process. Notably, as the reaction time extends beyond 40 h, the TON at 80 °C exceeds those observed at 90 and 100 °C (Fig. S10). This phenomenon is likely due to the partial transformation of (acetyl)Co species into other cobalt species at higher temperatures (90 and 100 °C), which reduces carbonylation activity over time. To understand the outstanding activity of catalyst system 2 ([(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp]/[(TPP)CrCl]), we first tested whether ion pair catalyst [(TPP)Cr]+[Co(CO)2dppp]–, similar to Coates catalyst [LA]+[Co(CO)4]–, could be generated in catalyst system 2 through the formation of CH3COCl. A reaction between [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] and [(TPP)CrCl] was performed in DME at 80 °C for 20 h under 60 bar CO. Before the reaction, the peaks of -COCH3 (A), P-CH2-CH2-CH2-P (B and C) and C6H5- (D and E) on the [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] were assigned as in Fig. 3(a) . The 1H NMR spectrum of [(CD3CO)Co(CO)2dppp] confirmed the correct assignment for the acetyl peak at 2.5 ppm (Fig. S11). Upon addition of [(TPP)CrCl] to [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp], the acetyl peak shifted from 2.5 to 2.4 ppm and all peaks associated with the dppp ligand shifted due to the paramagnetic effect of [(TPP)CrCl] species; for example, the phenyl group peak shifted from 7.6 ppm to 7.5 ppm, and -(CH2)3- peaks showed slight shifts (Figs. 3(a) and (b)). After running the reaction under the above conditions, the peak corresponding to CH3COCl (1.56 ppm) was not observed, and the peak associated with the cobalt-bound acetyl group remained at 2.4 ppm (Fig. S12). Next, we monitored the [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp]/[(TPP)CrCl]-cata- lyzed epoxide carbonylation by 1H NMR spectroscopy using a HO:Co:Cr ratio of 10:1:1 under carbonylation conditions (80 °C, 1, 2 or 10 h, DME, 60 bar CO). In the reported experiment, the catalyst-to-substrate ratio was approximately 1:10000. However, a 1:10 ratio was used in the experiment designed to observe changes in the catalyst's acetyl peak. This adjustment was made to ensure the detection of the catalyst ligand's NMR signals, which would otherwise be difficult to observe at the relatively low concentrations typically employed for the catalytic reaction. Within 1–2 h, β-lactone, along with the acetyl peak from [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp], was clearly identified in the ¹H NMR spectra (Fig. S13). Notably, the slight shifting of the corresponding peaks for β-lactone is attributed to the paramagnetic effect of the [(TPP)CrCl] species. To confirm the presence of β-lactone in the reaction product, GC-MS analysis of the crude reaction mixture further validated its formation, as shown in Figs. S14 and S15. However, upon extending the reaction time to 10 h, no β-lactone peaks were detected in the 1H NMR spectra (Fig. 3(c)). The absence of β-lactone at this time point may be attributed to its conversion into polymers and anhydride (Figs. 3(c), S16 and S17), resulting from the high concentration of [(TPP)CrCl] and cobalt species under elevated reaction temperatures. Notably, the crude reaction mixture exhibited a distinct peak at 2.4 ppm in the 1H NMR spectrum (Fig. 3(c)), indicating that the acetyl group bound to the cobalt center remained intact after the carbonylation of the epoxide. The maintenance of acetyl group was further proved using [(CD3CO)Co(CO)2dppp]-based catalyst system (Fig. S18). Based on these results, we inferred that the ion pair [(TPP)Cr]+[Co(CO)2dppp]– might not be generated in 2 during the carbonylation process. Furthermore, to demonstrate the essential role of the catalytic synergy between the cobalt site and the chromium site, [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] and [(TPP)CrCl] were used separately for HO carbonylation (Table S2, entries 1 and 2). As expected, no β-lactone formation was observed, likely due to the absence of an appropriate LA for epoxide activation and a cobalt species for CO insertion. The combination of [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] with nonmetallic compounds like bis(triphenylphosphine)- iminium chloride or other LA (e.g., (salph)CrCl, please confirm whether the “salph” is correct.) showed either inactivity or lower activity in HO carbonylation (Table S2, entries 3, and 4). This strongly suggests that efficient epoxide carbonylation necessitates the simultaneous presence of both nucleophilic cobalt species and a sterically hindered LA with the appropriate acidity. To elucidate the operational mechanism of the [(acetyl)Co(CO)2(dppp)] catalyst, its reaction coordinate has been calculated by performing density functional theory (DFT) computations with the BP86 functional and the 6-31g(d,p) basis set. For comparison with the previously established mechanism of the [Co(CO)4]– catalyst, propylene oxide (PO) was used as substrate, as its carbonylation involves equivalent thermodynamics as that of HO (Fig. S19). To save computational costs, the phenyl substituents of the dppp ligand were reduced to methyl groups by using dmpp (1,3-bis(dimethylphosphino) propane). The lowest-energy structure of the [(acetyl)Co(CO)2(dmpp)] complex was found to have the trigonal bipyramidal configuration with both CO ligands in the equatorial positions (Fig. S20). Notably, the acyl catalyst exhibited a lag in kinetics at 80 °C (Fig. 2). Thus, we also searched for its possible conversion to other catalytically active species. Under elevated temperature and increased CO pressure, the dissociation and subsequent substitution of the phosphine ligands with carbon monoxide were explored, yielding five different thermally-accessible candidates: [(acetyl)Co(CO)2(κ2-dmpp)], [(acetyl)Co(CO)2(κ1-dmpp)], [(acetyl)Co(CO)3], [(acetyl)Co(CO)3 (dmpp)], and [(acetyl)Co(CO)4] complexes (Fig. S21). The epoxide carbonylation reaction catalyzed by the [Co(CO)4]– catalyst involves a sequence of processes: nucleophilic attack of the cobalt center on epoxide, migration of CO from the cobalt center to the methylene group of epoxide, CO uptake by the cobalt center, and ring closure to generate lactone (Figs. 4(b ) and S22). All these steps were calculated to be exergonic with minor kinetic barriers, except for the last ring closure step, which was identified as the rate-determining step with a calculated ΔG ‡ of 24.1 kcal/mol. Contrarily, for all acyl species, the PO ring-opening processes were calculated to be endergonic and rate-determining, while the ring closure steps involved minor kinetic barriers (Figs. 4(a) and S23–S28). Among the five acyl structures examined, the four-coordinate structure with the acyl, monodentate phosphine, and two CO ligands exhibited the lowest rate-determining energy barrier of ΔG ‡ ~16.8 kcal/mol, although the conversion of the five-coordinate precursor to the four-coordinate active species would cost additional 12.5 kcal/mol (Figs. S21 and S24). The cobalt center of the four-coordinate [(acetyl)Co(CO)2(κ1-dmpp)] species were calculated to be stabilized by either η 2-type interactions with the acyl carbonyl group or agostic interactions with the acyl C–H group (Fig. 5 ). The former structure shows that the lone pair electrons of the acyl carbonyl oxygen donate electron density to the Co 3d-based LUMO. The latter structure, which can coexist with the former structure with ΔG minimally higher (3.7 kcal/mol) than the former, displays a slightly elongated C–H bond (1.12 Å) and the Co 3d-based LUMO interacting with the X–H σ-bonding MO. These interactions support that the four-coordinate Co1+ species can be stable despite the fact that they contain formally only 16 valence electrons. The distinction between the [Co(CO)4]– and [(acetyl)Co(CO)2(dmpp)] catalysts stems from their different oxidation states. For the ring-opening step, the Co1– center of the [Co(CO)4]– complex, with higher electron density, facilitates nucleophilic attack on the epoxide substrate more readily than the Co1+ center of the acyl complex (Fig. S29). Conversely, for the ring closure step, which involves the reduction of the cobalt center, the Co3+ center of the acyl catalyst's intermediate renders the ligated substrate more electrophilic and poised for nucleophilic attack of the alkoxide group ligated to the Cr(TPP) center than the Co1+ center of the [Co(CO)4]– catalyst's intermediate (Fig. S30). Note that the acyl catalyst is neutral while the [Co(CO)4]– catalyst is anionic. The rate-determining kinetic barriers calculated with the [(acetyl)Co(CO)2(dmpp)]/ [Cr(TPP)Cl] catalysts were greater than that of the [(TPP)Cr(THF)2]+[Co(CO)4]– catalyst (Fig. S31), which well account for the observed lower TOF of the acyl catalyst compared to [(TPP)Cr(THF)2]+[Co(CO)4]– at 60 °C. However, at temperatures exceeding 60 °C, the chemical species [(acetyl)Co(CO)2(dppp)] remains stable, while [Co(CO)4]– undergoes gradual decomposition and is gradually eliminated from the reaction system. Contrarily, the [(acetyl)Co(CO)2(dppp)]/ [(TPP)CrCl] system remain functional at high temperatures exceeding 80 °C, exhibiting an unprecedented high TOF at 100 °C. The experimental and computational findings reported in this paper, along with information derived from previously published literature, collectively provide the following insights into a plausible pathway for the [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp]/ [(TPP)CrCl] catalyst system in epoxide carbonylation (Scheme 2 ). The first step involves the generation of the coordinatively-unsaturated (acetyl)Co(CO)2L species through the dissociation of one phosphine ligand from the cobalt center. Consequently, the formed stable (acetyl)Co(CO)2L species can attack the methylene carbon, or potentially the methine carbon, albeit with lower likelihood, in the [(TPP)CrCl]-activated epoxide. This results in the formation of an 18-electron ring-opened intermediate (species A), which undergoes rapid CO insertion to yield species B. Subsequently, species B undergoes ring closure under a CO-abundant environment, leading to β-lactone formation, along with the release of free [(TPP)CrCl] and the regeneration of the active (acetyl)Co(CO)2L species. 4 Conclusions We addressed the limited TON issue associated with the reported catalyst [LA]+[Co(CO)4]–, which suffered from [Co(CO)4]– decomposition, leading to decreased stability and activity. To overcome this challenge, we drew inspiration from HCo(CO)4-catalyzed hydroformylation in industry and identified a novel nucleophile species for epoxide carbonylation. The designed catalyst system, consisting of [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] and [(TPP)CrCl], demonstrated remarkable catalytic performance, achieving an unprecedented initial TOF of 4700 h–1 at 100 °C and TON of 93000. Notably, the catalyst exhibited outstanding stability, operating at 80 °C for 168 h while maintaining a selective β-lactone generation. This impressive stability can be attributed to the high stability of the (acetyl)cobalt species, which is strongly stabilized by the η 2 coordination geometry or an agostic interaction of acyl cobalt. More importantly, in comparison with previous methods for the immobilization of cobalt carbonyl complexes [37,44,45], which mainly depend on the electrostatic interaction between [Co(CO)4]– anions and heterogenized LA cations, a novel method for the cobalt carbonyl immobilization was proposed, involving strong interactions of cobalt carbonyl motif with the acyl group on the heterogenized complex. We are currently working on developing an acyl cobalt-based heterogeneous catalyst for epoxide carbonylation, aiming to further enhance its practical applicability and potential for industrial-scale synthesis. coredata.dc:description: ABSTRACT Polyhydroxyalkanoate (PHA), a well-known biodegradable polymer, features β-lactones as its monomers, which can be selectively synthesized through ring-expansion carbonylation of epoxides using well-defined [Lewis acid]+[Co(CO)4]– catalysts. However, the decomposition of [Co(CO)4]– species at temperatures exceeding 80 °C presents a hurdle for the development of commercially viable processes under high-temperature reaction conditions to reduce reaction time. Drawing insights from stable {(acyl)Co(CO) n } intermediates involved in historical HCo(CO)4-catalyzed hydroformylation processes, we sought to the high-temperature catalytic activity of epoxide ring-expansion carbonylation. The developed catalyst system, [(acetyl)Co(CO)2dppp] and [(TPP)CrCl], exhibited exceptional catalytic performance with an unprecedented initial turnover frequency of 4700 h–1 at 100 °C and a turnover numbers of 93000. Notably, the catalyst displayed outstanding stability, operating at 80 °C for 168 h while selectively generating β-lactones.
